div.p: Writer; occasional assistant to Schenker for more than twenty years.

div.head: Mittelmann and Schenker
div.p: Mittelmann is first mentioned in Schenker's diary on November 3, 1902 (OJ 1/4, p. 9: "By faithful translation Mittelmann puts me on so many other scents"); again on September 3, 1906 (p. 19), October 22, 1906 (p. 22), and February 4, 1907 (p. 33). By 1912, he had apparently fallen on hard times, and Schenker tried to help him by employing him in proof-correcting and similar work for, e.g., Die letzten funf Sonaten von Beethoven, and by seeking support for him from his own wealthy contacts. He was evidently an educated man, for Schenker's diary for July 24, 1921 notes: "Mrs. Pairamall is learning Greek with him." (OJ 3/2, p. 2368), and that for June 22, 1926 (OJ 3/8, p. 2832) remarks " Mittelmann in the evening: as fresh as ever, shows strong continuous memory, recites Greek and Polish verses! stays until 9:45."

Around the end of World War I he was allegedly involved in the black market (OJ 2/10, p. 837: "Mittelmann turns out to be a black marketeer: we order twine from him."), consequently he supplied Heinrich and Jeanette with unobtainable commodities. Schenker continued to use him as an amanuensis at least late into the 1920s.

His birth date is deduced from the statement in Schenker's diary on December 10, 1927 that Mittelmann had "celebrated on this day: his 71st birthday!" (OJ 4/1, p. 3148). That is corroborated by the statement on March 23, 1925 (OJ 3/7, pp. 2800-2801): Mittelmann in the evening; according to his birth certificate, he is 69 years old! He is healthy and alert, was talkative the entire evening, apparently because we gave him the opportunity to show us his exercises in construction.

In 1916, Mittelmann is recorded in Lehmann's Vienna Addressbook as living at Vienna XVII, Wurlitzergasse 89 ‒ which is still nowadays (2013) a shelter for the homeless. His last address in 1942 was Vienna X, Alxingergasse 97.

As a Jew, Mittelmann was deported by the Nazis to the concentration camp Theresienstadt (Terezín) in German-occupied Bohemia on August 27‒28, 1942 (two months after Jeanette Schenker), on transport IV/9, no. 60 (1,008 people being taken, of which 970 were murdered and 38 survived), and was murdered there on November 16 of the same year.

div.head: Correspondence between Mittelmann and Schenker
div.p: A great deal passed between the two men, but only one postcard, from Mittelmann to Schenker, survives in OJ 8/1 (1913: misfiled among postcards from Schenker to Moriz Violin), and also two postcards from him to Violin as OJ 70/28 (1912).
